Award.AwardTitle: Science Policy Research Report: Entrepreneurial Career Opportunities for Science and Engineering Postdoctoral Researchers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Academic postdoctoral research positions were originally intended to provide additional training in preparation for tenure-track university faculty positions. Many postdoctoral researchers are currently unlikely to obtain a faculty job. These individuals possess scientific knowledge of value to science and technology-based companies. This project examines evidence on university and government programs that promising career alternative in the private sector. The project documents the needs of current and potential employers to understand factors that will better prepare postdocs to work in the private sector. The project recommends new programs and policies to prepare and assist postdoctoral researchers for careers in corporations and startups.


This project reviews research that examines the purpose and structure as well as the career-related benefits and challenges of these positions. This project will conduct original case studies of existing career development programs focused on preparing postdocs to work in corporations and startup companies. The research will also focus on how non-academic career outcomes may vary for postdocs based on their race and gender, which are two critical considerations for leveraging the benefits of a diverse science and technology talent pool. Based on these findings, the project will result in policy recommendations for government and university leaders to improve postdoctoral researcher career outcomes and increase the public return on its research investment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Following labor market studies, this project assumed that most university postdocs will not find academic jobs and must thus transition to non-academic careers. A successful transition to non-academic employment will not only maximize the nation’s return on its R&D investments, it will also help postdocs obtain meaningful employment that utilizes their significant scientific talents. This study investigated factors that influence the transition of university postdocs to non-academic scientific careers and explored programs and policies that enable them to better do so.

After reviewing the relevant literature related to non-academic career transitions among PhDs and postdocs, the study team reviewed the websites of 300 research universities ranked by R&D spending, examining the extent to which universities made postdoc career support programs available, including those focused on non-academic careers. Available services were catalogued and analyzed. The project team also interviewed university personnel to understand the motivations for establishing postdoc career services (especially those related to non-academic careers), specific services offered, as well as successes and opportunities relating to the programs. In its investigation of factors that influence the transition of university postdocs to non-academic scientific career, the project team also interviewed nearly 100 postdocs at five top research universities.

The project findings show that postdocs face multiple individual, PI, as well as organizational and policy factors, including the lack of relevant skills, absence of support—and in some cases opposition—from their principal investigators. Additionally, they also face poor availability of non-academic career preparation opportunities, among others. Viewed collectively, these elements likely hinder a postdoc’s move to non-academic scientific positions and thus have consequences for postdoc career trajectories and, by extension, the utilization of publicly-funded knowledge. Postdocs are thus in need of knowledge and skills that will allow them to pursue and obtain non-academic employment.

The project shows that universities increasingly recognize the importance of providing postdocs career services. However, these offerings are relatively modest with only a small group of universities providing services focused on non-academic career preparation, with even fewer providing postdocs with experiential learning opportunities. Policy recommendations stemming from the project including language in legislative reauthorizations such as the America COMPETES Act that includes postdoc career attainment goals as a goal for research awards, promote university-industry partnerships that could involve postdocs in experiential non-academic career training, and explore the creation of alternative paths for postdocs that may utilize their scientific training to support entrepreneurship and technology transfer to industry.

The results of this project are available in two publications. The first will be an edited volume of reports which focuses on the distribution and composition of university career development programs for postdocs. The second, an article entitled “Factors that influence the transition of university postdocs to non-academic scientific careers: An exploratory study” will be published in Research Policy.
